title.narrative: Främja ungdomsarbete genom stöd till TVET
Promoting Youth Employment Through Support to TVET

description.narrative: The overall objective of the contribution is to lift beneficiaries from poverty by increasing their chances to gain productive employment. The expected outcome is a robust and inclusive Technical and Vocation Education and Training (TVET) system that is responsive to economic needs.

Svenska ambassaden i Monrovia har fått en förfrågan från UNIDO för finansiering av USD 6,213,870, uppskattat 55 miljoner kronor för att genomföra Promoting youth employment by supporting technical and vocational education i Liberia för perioden 2018–2023. UNIDO kommer vara huvudansvariga för att implementera projektet.
Projektets övergripande mål är att lyfta unga från fattigdom genom att ge dem ökade möjligheter till en produktiv anställning via ett robust och inkluderande TVET-system (Technical Vocational Education and Training), med kännedom om marknadens ekonomiska behov. Projektet kommer bidra till följande resultat: - ökad kapacitet hos lärare genom formell lärarutbildning som fokuserar på yrkesförberedande utbildning - stärkt kompentens bland befolkningensfärdigheter så att det överensstämmer med de ekonomiska behoven (till exempel infrastrukturutveckling och jordbruk) - öka engagemanget hos privata sektorn för delaktighet inom TVET-sektorn
Utveckling av ungdomar kommer vara i fokus, vilket kommer uppnås genom att stärka och bygga på nuvarande institutionell kapaciteterna hos Liberias tekniska och yrkesförberande utbildnings system för att leverera relevanta kurser som svarar till behoven hos ekonomin.
Projektet kommer adressera både efterfrågan och utbudet på arbetsmarknadens genom att utrusta ungdomar med färdigheter som ökar deras möjlighet till anställning, och som resultat minskar nuvarande hinder för företag att expandera på grund av brist på kompetent arbetskraft.

UNIDO has applied to Sida for funding of USD 6,213,870, aproximately 55 million SEK, to carry out the promoting youth employment by supporting technical and vocational education in Liberia programme during the period 2018-2023. UNIDO will be the main implementing partner.
The proposed intervention overall objective is to lift beneficiaries from poverty by increasing their chances to gain productive employment through a robust and inclusive TVET system (Technical Vocational Education and Training) that is responsive to economic needs. The intervention will support the following outputs: - improved capacity of teachers through participation in formal teacher training for vocational education; - strengthened human capital to correspond to economic needs (e.g. in infrastructure development and agribusiness); - and increased participation of the private-sector in stewardship and engagement with TVET sector at the school level.
Emphasis will be placed on youth development. This will be achieved by strengthening and building on the existing institutional capacity of Liberia's vocational training system to deliver up-to-date training courses relevant to the requirements of the economy.
The intervention will address both labor demand and supply by equipping young persons with skills that increase their employability and earnings, and by removing bottlenecks to expanding profitable businesses due to skills shortages.

tag.narrative: 4.3 - By 2030, ensure equal access for all women and men to affordable and quality technical, vocational and tertiary education, including university.
4.3 - Senast 2030 säkerställa alla kvinnor och män lika tillgång till yrkesutbildning och eftergymnasial utbildning, inklusive högskoleutbildning, av god kvalitet till en överkomlig kostnad.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
8.6 - By 2020, substantially reduce the proportion of youth not in employment, education or training.
8.6 - Till 2020 väsentligt minska den andel ungdomar som varken arbetar eller studerar.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The period under review covers primarily the inception phase, procurement process for project operations equipment, arrangements for project office set up, conducting key studies and technical assessments in preparation for actual implementation. The six months inception period (January to June 2019) was successful because it delivered on all the expected deliverables. Project staff and consultants were recruited, and the logical framework was revised to include impact indicators as well as indicators on gender and inclusion. Baselines and targets for some activities were established. Technical needs assessment was done, and it provided insights into the current status of teacher trainings at the Voinjama Multilateral High School (VMHS) and the Booker Washington Institute (BWI) that would guide the intervention. Infrastructure needs assessment was carried out; detailing the current structure of the facility as well as the work that needs to be done. A labor market needs assessment was done, and five vocations were identified as the ones that the current market in Lofa county demands; agriculture, welding/metal goods fabrication, carpentry/woodwork, electricity, automotive repair (light engines), and information and communication technology. Under Output 1; improved capacity of teachers, administrators and principals through participation in formal TVET teacher training and Vocational Training Center (VTC) administration/management training programmes, the follow results have been attained: Twenty TVET teachers have been recruited for overseas teachers training. A study tour to expose officials responsible for TVET in Liberia was undertaken to Kenya and Zambia. Relevant staff of the Ministry of Education (MoE) and the Ministry of Youth and Sports (MoYS) participated and documented good practices of properly functioning TVET governance and training delivery systems that could be replicated in Liberia. 8 staff from MOE/MOYS, 17 administrative staff from the TVET institutions (including two from Voinjama Multilateral High School (VMHS)) and four representatives of youth groups were introduced to monitoring and evaluation. Preliminary work began on a TVET Center for Professional Training, Development, Research, and Innovation (TCPTRI) to be hosted by the BWI, which will act as the interface between TVET institutions and international sources to broker and coordinate TVET capacity development. Under Output 2; TVET provider infrastructure and delivery system is upgraded to correspond to economic needs, the following have been undertaken: training equipment specification for Liberia and VMHS has been developed, and infrastructure designed work at the VMHS has commenced. The Liberian TVET system has been benchmarked/compared against the national TVET systems of nine other African countries. This comparison established that Liberia had the lowest level of comparative matching with the international best practice model of TVET system at 36.33%. To make a comparison, the highest comparator score was the one of South Africa at 64.84%. Under Output 3; increased participation of the private sector in stewardship and engagement with TVET sector at school level including in curriculum development and TVET delivery, the team developed an understanding of the formal and informal private sectors in Voinjama and Lofa County, and generated information required to ensure that TVET programmes are tailored to the needs of the local labour market. Links have been established with over 60 small to medium sized enterprises in 14 sectors. Regrading Output 4; gender sensitized measures to foster enrolment and retention of female, vulnerable youth and people with disabilities, a gender-specific needs assessment was carried out and established various factors influencing female participation in TVET in Lofa County. These included financing, family influence, pregnancy or forced/early marriage, influence of peers, self-motivation, gender stereotypes and lack of quality TVET courses with the necessary practical components. In joint effort with the MoE Director for Special and Inclusive Education, an assessment to define education needs and course delivery to persons with disability was carried out. Evidence shows that officials, school administration, teachers and students lack awareness of barriers to access TVET by disabled students but are willing to address this and take action. Most TVET teachers lack skills for inclusive education. Accordingly, VMHS infrastructure upgrade has taken into consideration barrier-free aspects to cater for students with disabilities. Sweden and the EU Delegation in Liberia agreed that since UNIDO is implementing TVET programs for both donors, a cost-sharing formula of 83% (EU) with 6 schools and 13% (Sweden) with 1 school will be executed to cater to joint project human resources and operational arrangements.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
